Award.AwardTitle: Characteristics of Bolus formation from Breaking Internal Waves on Shelf Slopes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1133380
Koseff

The upslope, shoreward transport of colder, nutrient-rich waters from below the ocean thermocline is thought to be critical to coastal ecosystems such as coral reefs. Internal bores, or boluses, generated by the breaking of shoaling internal waves on the slope provide a mechanism for this cross-shelf transport of dense water. Indeed, observations confirm that as internal waves propagate into shallow water, the waves steepen, which can lead to breaking and, at times, the generation of turbulent boluses of dense fluid which continue to travel inshore, mixing with ambient surface water. This mechanism is thought to be a significant mechanism for the transfer of nutrients, sediment, and larvae between deep waters and the shelf environment. Furthermore, bolus-driven transport has the potential to transport contaminants from offshore sewage outfalls at depth into the near-shore environment, posing risks for human health through fishing and direct exposure at beaches. However, questions still remain regarding internal bore propagation and transport, including what conditions cause the formation of internal bores. Thus, this project will investigate the internal bore formation and mass transport processes using laboratory experiments.

To date, the knowledge of internal bore formation, propagation, and associated mass transport is fairly limited. The overall goals of the research, therefore, are to (1) quantitatively determine the physical conditions which control the development of internal bores from shoaling internal waves, and develop models and parameterizations for this, and (2) relate initial flow parameters to the mass transport and fluid entrainment of internal bores. A series of laboratory experiments in the internal wave facility of the Stanford Environmental Fluid Mechanics Laboratory will study the shoaling of internal waves on uniform slope/shelf topography in a two-layered system. Quantitative flow visualization techniques, including Planar Laser-Induced Fluorescence (PLIF) and Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) will allow a detailed study of the effect of variations in the initial flow conditions, such as incoming wave amplitude and frequency, on bolus formation and propagation. Additional velocity and density field data will quantify the mass transport of internal bore propagation, as well as quantify the bolus entrainment of ambient fluid.

Overall, the project will strongly complement ongoing field studies examining mass transfer issues in coastal ecosystems. Additionally, the expected results will not only provide insight to the physical mechanisms of shoaling internal waves, but will also have implications for biological processes affected by hydrodynamics and mass transfer in shallow coastal systems. Finally, studies such as these can be invaluable to interpreting the "snapshots" that ocean data often gives, and in perhaps directing further ocean measurements. Results from this work will be of use to researchers studying near-coastal transport and mixing processes in coral reefs, kelp forests, seagrass communities, as well as those concerned with human health impacts from ocean outfalls and other antrhopogenic discharges. Finally, the methodologies and techniques for PLIF and PIV in stratified flows that are further developed and refined here will be of use to the experimental fluid mechanics community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The upslope, shoreward transport of colder, nutrient-rich waters from below the ocean thermocline is thought to be critical to the functioning of coastal ecosystems such as coral reefs and kelp forests. As internal waves propagate into shallow water, the waves steepen, which can lead to breaking and, at times, the generation of turbulent bores of dense fluid. These formations of sub-thermocline water continue to travel inshore, mixing with ambient surface water. The propagation of internal bores is a significant mechanism for the transfer of nutrients, sediment, and larvae between deep waters and the shelf environment. In addition, bores may provide localized, intermittent cooling relief from the warmer, ambient surface waters around coral reefs.

In this project we examined the formation and propagation of internal boluses from breaking internal wavetrains on a uniform slope in a two-layer stratified fluid. Bolus formation from periodic wavetrains was qualitatively explored and compared with observations made by studies employing different wave types.  Additionally, the physical conditions for both bolus formation and suppression was explored, as well as how the characteristics of the boluses relate to these conditions.  In an effort to link the results with oceanic observations, these physical conditions are expressed with quantities that are more readily measured in the field.  We addressed the following overarching questions: (i) What parameters of the flow and environment control the formation of internal bores in a two-layer stratified system? ; (ii) How do the physical characteristics of the resulting bores depend on the initial flow conditions? ; (iii) What parameters of the flow and environment control the formation of internal bores in a linearly stratified system? ; (iv) How do the physical characteristics of the resulting bores depend on the initial flow conditions?

Several sets of experiments were conducted involving both a two layer stratified system and a linearly stratified system. In the course of doing these experiments we gained a number of very important insights into the bolus formation process.  During the initial formation process, the backflow of a previous shoaling wave interacts with the overturning front edge of the next incoming wave, leading to the development of a positively rotating vortex with substantial engulfment of the backflow. As the wave forcing is increased, the back end of the overturning wave has an increased amount of forward momentum, leading it to attempt to move over the vortex. In certain cases, the back end of the wave will collapse on top of the vortex, leading to what we have called a top-breaking event. As the initial wave nonlinearity increases even further, bolus formation is hindered, and is instead replaced by the propagation of turbulent surges of dense water upslope. Using the results obtained from experiments that expanded the range of wave forcing applied to the slope, we were able to discern that these bolus formation types are more dependent upon the wave Froude number Fr and wave steepness parameter ka than the wave Reynolds number, as previously thought.

For the second set of major experiments in linear stratification a tunable wave generator was utilized to produce a high-quality mode-1 wave field in a linearly stratified fluid. Modal analysis results indicate the formation of a mode-1 wave, which transforms into higher modes as the wave interacts with the topography. The wave-slope interactions produced a range of responses including the formation of upslope-surging internal boluses that propagate across the shelf flat. Bolus formation was primarily dependent on the wave Froude number and the ratio of the topographic slope to the internal wave characteristic slope. These results compare well with published two-dimensional numerical simulations with some deviations, which may be attributable to the effects of the three-dimensionality of the experiments. The ultimate finding of this part of our study is that as low-mode internal waves interact with topography energy is transferred to higher modes and the formation of internal beams and/or internal boluses can occur.

 

The completed work has expanded the scope of previously conducted research and provided high-resolution measurements for the density and velocity structures of internal bores. Additionally, our results have provided insight to the physical mechanisms of shoaling internal waves, including implications for biological processes affected by hydrodynamics and mass transfer in shallow coastal systems. The completed research has also resulted in the attainment of advanced degrees in engineering for two female graduate students both of whom have gone on to careers in STEM fields, and also provided research experiences for a number of undergraduate students at Stanford University. Finally, the data this work will be of use to researchers studying near-coastal transport and mixing processes in coral reefs, kelp forests, seagrass communities, as well as those concerned with human health impacts from ocean outfalls and other anthropogenic discharges.
